member.name: M:SdlDotNet.Graphics.Sprites.Sprite.IntersectsWithRadius(SdlDotNet.Graphics.Sprites.Sprite,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Checks for collision between two sprites using a radius from the center of the sprites.
member.param: The radius of the current sprite. Defaults to the radius of the sprite.
The other sprite's radius. Defaults to the radius of the sprite.
The size of the buffer zone for collision detection. Defaults to 0.
member.returns: True if they intersect, false if they don't.
member.remarks: If they radius is not given, it calculates it for you using half the width plus half the height.

member.name: M:SdlDotNet.Graphics.Sprites.Sprite.IntersectsWithRadius(SdlDotNet.Graphics.Sprites.Sprite,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Checks for collision between two sprites using a radius from the center of the sprites.
member.param: The radius of the current sprite. Defaults to the radius of the sprite.
The other sprite's radius. Defaults to the radius of the sprite.
member.returns: True if they intersect, false if they don't.
member.remarks: The offset defaults to 0.

member.summary: Checks for collision between two sprites using a radius from the center of the sprites.
member.returns: True if they intersect, false if they don't.

member.name: M:SdlDotNet.Graphics.Sprites.Sprite.IntersectsWithRadius(SdlDotNet.Graphics.Sprites.Sprite)
member.summary: Checks for collision between two sprites using a radius from the center of the sprites.

summary.para: Represents a Image that can be drawn on a Sdl.Surface.
The image can be loaded from from a file, a System.Drawing.Bitmap, or a byte array.
Supported image formats follows the development cycle of SDL_Image. Currently, supported and planned supported image formats are:
summary.code: Surface image = Surface("mybitmap.jpg") image.Blit(screen, new Rectangle(new Point(0,0),image.Size))

member.name: T:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MinifyingOption
member.summary:
The texture minifying function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area greater than one texture element. There are six defined minifying functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.
A mipmap is an ordered set of arrays representing the same image at progressively lower resolutions. If the texture has dimensions 2nx2m, there are max(n,m)+1 mipmaps. The first mipmap is the original texture, with dimensions 2nx2m. Each subsequent mipmap has dimensions 2k-1x2l-1, where 2kx2l are the dimensions of the previous mipmap, until either k=0 or l=0. At that point, subsequent mipmaps have dimension 1x2l-1 or 2k-1x1 until the final mipmap, which has dimension 1x1. To define the mipmaps, call glTexImage1D, glTexImage2D, glCopyTexImage1D, or glCopyTexImage2D with the level argument indicating the order of the mipmaps. Level 0 is the original texture; level max(n,m) is the final 1x1 mipmap.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MinifyingOption.Nearest
member.summary: Returns the value of the texture element that is nearest (in Manhattan distance) to the center of the pixel being textured.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MinifyingOption.Linear
member.summary: Returns the weighted average of the four texture elements that are closest to the center of the pixel being textured. These can include border texture elements, depending on the values of GL_TEXTURE_WRAP_S and GL_TEXTURE_WRAP_T, and on the exact mapping.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MinifyingOption.NearestMipMapNearest
member.summary: Chooses the mipmap that most closely matches the size of the pixel being textured and uses the GL_NEAREST criterion (the texture element nearest to the center of the pixel) to produce a texture value.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MinifyingOption.LinearMipMapNearest
member.summary: Chooses the mipmap that most closely matches the size of the pixel being textured and uses the GL_LINEAR criterion (a weighted average of the four texture elements that are closest to the center of the pixel) to produce a texture value.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MinifyingOption.NearestMipMapLinear
member.summary: Chooses the two mipmaps that most closely match the size of the pixel being textured and uses the GL_NEAREST criterion (the texture element nearest to the center of the pixel) to produce a texture value from each mipmap. The final texture value is a weighted average of those two values.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MinifyingOption.LinearMipMapLinear
member.summary: Chooses the two mipmaps that most closely match the size of the pixel being textured and uses the GL_LINEAR criterion (a weighted average of the four texture elements that are closest to the center of the pixel) to produce a texture value from each mipmap. The final texture value is a weighted average of those two values.

member.name: T:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MagnificationOption
member.summary: The texture magnification function is used when the pixel being textured maps to an area less than or equal to one texture element. It sets the texture magnification function to either GL_NEAREST or GL_LINEAR. GL_NEAREST is generally faster than GL_LINEAR, but it can produce textured images with sharper edges because the transition between texture elements is not as smooth. The initial value of GL_TEXTURE_MAG_FILTER is GL_LINEAR.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MagnificationOption.Nearest
member.summary: Returns the value of the texture element that is nearest (in Manhattan distance) to the center of the pixel being textured.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.MagnificationOption.Linear
member.summary: Returns the weighted average of the four texture elements that are closest to the center of the pixel being textured. These can include border texture elements, depending on the values of GL_TEXTURE_WRAP_S and GL_TEXTURE_WRAP_T, and on the exact mapping.

member.name: P:SdlDotNet.Graphics.SurfaceGl.MinFilter
member.summary:
Gets and Sets The texture minifying function is used whenever the pixel being textured maps to an area greater than one texture element. There are six defined minifying functions. Two of them use the nearest one or nearest four texture elements to compute the texture value. The other four use mipmaps.
A mipmap is an ordered set of arrays representing the same image at progressively lower resolutions. If the texture has dimensions 2nx2m, there are max(n,m)+1 mipmaps. The first mipmap is the original texture, with dimensions 2nx2m. Each subsequent mipmap has dimensions 2k-1x2l-1, where 2kx2l are the dimensions of the previous mipmap, until either k=0 or l=0. At that point, subsequent mipmaps have dimension 1x2l-1 or 2k-1x1 until the final mipmap, which has dimension 1x1. To define the mipmaps, call glTexImage1D, glTexImage2D, glCopyTexImage1D, or glCopyTexImage2D with the level argument indicating the order of the mipmaps. Level 0 is the original texture; level max(n,m) is the final 1x1 mipmap.

member.name: P:SdlDotNet.Graphics.SurfaceGl.MagnificationFilter
member.summary: Gets and Sets The texture magnification function is used when the pixel being textured maps to an area less than or equal to one texture element. It sets the texture magnification function to either GL_NEAREST or GL_LINEAR. GL_NEAREST is generally faster than GL_LINEAR, but it can produce textured images with sharper edges because the transition between texture elements is not as smooth. The initial value of GL_TEXTURE_MAG_FILTER is GL_LINEAR.

member.name: P:SdlDotNet.Graphics.SurfaceGl.WrapS
member.summary: Gets and Sets The wrap parameter for texture coordinate s to either GL_CLAMP or GL_REPEAT. GL_CLAMP causes s coordinates to be clamped to the range [0,1] and is useful for preventing wrapping artifacts when mapping a single image onto an object. GL_REPEAT causes the integer part of the s coordinate to be ignored; the GL uses only the fractional part, thereby creating a repeating pattern. Border texture elements are accessed only if wrapping is set to GL_CLAMP. Initially, GL_TEXTURE_WRAP_S is set to GL_REPEAT.

member.name: P:SdlDotNet.Graphics.SurfaceGl.WrapT
member.summary: Gets and Sets The wrap parameter for texture coordinate t to either GL_CLAMP or GL_REPEAT. GL_CLAMP causes t coordinates to be clamped to the range [0,1] and is useful for preventing wrapping artifacts when mapping a single image onto an object. GL_REPEAT causes the integer part of the s coordinate to be ignored; the GL uses only the fractional part, thereby creating a repeating pattern. Border texture elements are accessed only if wrapping is set to GL_CLAMP. Initially, GL_TEXTURE_WRAP_T is set to GL_REPEAT.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.VideoModes.AsynchronousBlit
member.summary: Enables the use of asynchronous updates of the display surface. This will usually slow down blitting on single CPU machines, but may provide a speed increase on SMP systems.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.VideoModes.DoubleBuffering
member.summary: Enable hardware double buffering; only valid with . Calling Surface.Update() will flip the buffers and update the screen. All drawing will take place on the surface that is not displayed at the moment. If double buffering could not be enabled then will just update on the entire screen.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.VideoModes.FullScreen
member.summary: SDL.NET will attempt to use a fullscreen mode. If a hardware resolution change is not possible (for whatever reason), the next higher resolution will be used and the display window centered on a black background.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.VideoModes.OpenGL
member.summary: Create an OpenGL rendering context. You should have previously set OpenGL video attributes with SDL_GL_SetAttribute.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.VideoModes.Resizable
member.summary: Create a resizable window. When the window is resized by the user a event is generated and Video.SetVideoMode can be called again with the new size.

member.name: F:SdlDotNet.Graphics.VideoModes.NoFrame
member.summary: If possible, NoFrame causes SDL to create a window with no title bar or frame decoration. Fullscreen modes automatically have this flag set.

member.name: M:SdlDotNet.Graphics.Video.SetVideoMode
member.summary: Sets the video mode of the application. This overload is simply for initializing the video subsystem. It is useful when integrating with System.Windows.Forms
member.remarks: The surface will not have a height nor width. The surface will use the current bit depth. The surface will not be resizable. The surface will be an SDL surface for 2D drawing. The surface will be in windowed mode. The surface will have a frame unless it is fullscreen. The surface will be a "software" surface. Hardware surfaces are problematic and should only be used under certain circumstances.

member.summary: The base abstract particle emitter class. This is to be derived from when creating new particle emitters.
member.remarks: You can use the Random property to get random numbers or the GetRange function to retrieve ranged random numbers. The base particle attributes are handled by the particle system. All you have to change are the derived properties.

member.remarks: Some implementations of the particle class include ParticlePixel and ParticleSprite.
